Hello everyone, my name is Matt Simon.

which sounds very intimidating and a bit heavy.

on some solutions here

First of all, we have Dee and Steve Allen.
They are microplastic researchers extraordinaire,

Thank you everybody for being here today.
Thanks for having us. Thanks for having us.
Sure, sure.

you were in a caravan in the Scottish countryside,

[Steve] Yes.

because of what you're studying.
Walk us through what you're doing out there

Well, we survived the initial COVID
lockdown in a caravan at a friend's place

and now we've returned to the middle of France
on the Rhine river on our boat,
just waiting for all the madness to stop

So what is it?
So what is microplastic?
How do you define that?
And I think this is a good way to start
to talk about your research.
Where are you finding these tiny bits of plastic?
Everywhere. [laughing]
So our research focuses on atmospherics.
We went about looking up in the air
purely because we found plastics in the oceans.
Plastics has been found in the rivers,
in the river sediment, it's being found in soil.

equality in the plastics that we would expect.
So we have an idea of how much is being thrown out,
how much is being lost out of the waste management system.
But we don't know where that that missing gap is
between the amount that we know
is actually being put to waste
and the amount that's being produced, there's a gap.
So it's a leaky system.
We don't have a circular economy.
And we want to know where all of that plastic has gone.
And the last environmental compartment
to look at is the atmosphere.
So we started looking up in the atmosphere,
well, in the air, that's floating around you all the time.
We started in France and we've sort of moved globally
to identify where these microplastics might be.
Microplastic is a slightly contentious term.
It depends on who you talk to as to what size it is.
It's basically anything that's under
five millimeters in size,
all the way down to one micron
and then below one micron is a nanometer,
which is a nanoplastic.
So that's not a medical definition,
that's a scientific definition.
Yeah, yeah, and you know,
you're finding these tiny bits of plastics
on remote mountaintops, and it's very clear
that this is blowing in the wind,
and it's also blowing up into the Arctic.
It has been found in formerly pristine areas up there.
And I think that brings us nicely
to Isla's research, also looking at the Arctic.
But looking at some really troubling things
when it comes to the climate change.
Given the fact that the Arctic is warming twice,
if not more, faster than the rest of the planet.

And I understand you actually have some new research
that came out this week that you could share.
Excellent, yeah.
so I work in the Arctic, and normal summers,
I'm actually up in the Arctic.
For the last, or,
I would have been for the last few months,
collecting our field research.
This summer has been a bit different,
but the research continues,
this time more at the computer.
So I work in the Canadian Arctic,
and I work with datasets around the Arctic.
And what we're seeing is this greening of tundra ecosystem.
So you have the climate warming over the last few decades.
And what we've been doing is monitoring plants
on the ground and from the air
using drones and with my research team,
which is called Team Shrub, tracking this change
that's going on in the high latitudes of the planet.
And so we're using fixed wing plane drones,
we're using the multi copter drones,
some of the same types of drone platforms
that you could buy commercially or fly yourself.
And then we're monitoring these vast tundra landscapes
that have this green surface of plants at the top.
And what we're seeing from space
and satellite is this greening pattern.
And what we're trying to figure out on the ground
is exactly what that greeting signal means
in terms of a change on the ground,
and what that means for the carbon cycle,
which is all a part of this global climate system.
And whether basically warming in the Arctic
is going to amplify the climate change
that we see across the planet.
Yeah, a couple of things that I want to follow up on.
Greening sounds nice, generally speaking,
but that is not the case in the Arctic.
I was hoping you could follow up
on a couple of maybe some knock on effects
that we might be seeing ecologically,
you know, both in the Arctic itself,
but looking at Earth as an Earth system,
how might the greening of the Arctic
then further feed into these patterns of climate change?
Yeah, so the vegetation we're seeing,
vegetation changes in the Arctic
is an increase in the plants.
So you're up above the tree line
and where you are in the Arctic,
we have different species that are sort of
shorter than trees, but growing taller over time.
So we've got these shrubs in the system,
the woody plants that are kind of the trees in the tundra,
and then also grasses and other species
that can benefit when the temperatures are warmer
and the growing seasons are longer.
So we think that's what's causing
climate change in these systems.
And that's kind of the theme of the new paper
that you mentioned before that came out yesterday.
We were working with higher resolution satellite data
and comparing that to change on the ground
and also the warming patterns that we've seen in the Arctic.
And in that paper, we found that yeah,
over 30% of the Arctic is greening,
so it is a really pervasive signal.
And we think that in some cases
that's trapping more carbon in the planet,
but it's also changing the Arctic in different ways.
So one way is as those shrubs tend to get taller,
that traps more snow in the winter,
and snow acts like a blanket in these systems,
and it insulates the ground from the cold temperatures
in the air in the wintertime.
So it's kind of like on a cold winter day,
if you put an extra blanket on your bed, you're warmer.
And that's a problem, 'cause we don't really want
the soil to be warmer in these systems,
because that allows microbes
to keep munching away on the carbon that's in there.
It allows the permafrost,
which is the permanently frozen ground,
to stay warmer in the winter,
which means that in the summer,
it thaws to a deeper level
and all of that could potentially
be releasing carbon into the atmosphere.
So what we're concerned about in these systems
as the vegetation increases
is that we might be seeing some positive feedbacks
that are going to release carbon to the atmosphere.
And there's quite a lot of carbon.
So I was trying to look up exactly how much carbon
we're talking about in these high latitude systems.
And it's somewhere between 1000 and 2000 petagrams
of carbon, which NASA put out in this example.
So that's, if you imagine a coal train
and each of those coal train has these cars full of coal
and the coal is mostly carbon, the train would be,
I think something like 200,000 miles long,
that's the amount of carbon that's in
the high latitudes that could be released to the atmosphere.
So if it was released, then that could as much as double
the atmospheric CO2 concentrations, possibly more,
and that would create this feedback that means
greater warming, not just in the Arctic,
but for the planet as a whole.
So the Arctic's warmed by about two degrees already,
and we're expecting it to warm by six to 10 degrees
over the next 100 years, maybe more.
So all of these feedbacks and this change,
it's already happening up there,
and we're just trying to figure out
how fast and what it'll mean
for all of us on the planet. Yeah.
Yeah, and speaking of feedback, Steve and Dee,
I think your research is particularly fascinating
because you're covering so much
of what we're starting to call the microplastic cycle,
the way that these particles are moving
between land and sea and air.
You know, kind of building off some of the stuff
that I was talking about,
these global systems that are all interconnected,
I was hoping you could speak to
what we're learning about this microplastic cycle,
how these little bits of plastic
are actually moving around the planet.
Yeah, I think we often forget
that we live on a ball,
and that ball is inside a bubble.
So there are no borders,
nature doesn't see borders,
and certainly pollution doesn't.
So whatever we do in one area affects everybody else.
And plastic is a prime example of covering long distances.
We're still looking for the sources at the moment,
we're doing a lot of work on trying to pinpoint that
so that we can try and mitigate the problem.
But yeah, as Isla was mentioning,
the amount of carbon in the atmosphere
is having an effect on the Arctic Circle.
And plastic of course, is a producer of carbon.
The whole process, the whole lifecycle of plastic
from taking the fracking gas out of the ground,
turning into ethylene,
from there all the way through to landfill.
And this imaginary recycling,
where it's actually just being shipped off
to places like Malaysia,
where they either chop it up
and burn it or put it straight in the river.
It's all, every step along that route
is adding to the carbon footprint,
but it's also adding to the points
where it can leak out into the environment.
And that's where we're finding it in the very,
very small material. So part of the work
that we do looks at how far it transports.
And so we can find where these particles
are arriving in the world.
So we've got samples from Africa, from France.
We've got some samples from the Arctic, we've got places,
we've got air samples from all over the world.
And everywhere you look, you find plastic.
Though we haven't found a sample that doesn't
have any atmospheric plastic.
And what do you find falling down to the ground
and what you find blowing through the air
are slightly different,
so they are a slightly different particle size.
They have slightly different dynamics and shapes
and the types of material that they are.
But what we can do is when we know those quantities
and we know where we found them,
we can then model where this material goes.
So you do a back trajectory model and look at its history,
and if your samples are taken in the right way,
you can actually create a map saying,
I caught this sample on this location.
So we know that there's pieces of plastic
that we potentially are breathing in,
that are on this location.
So they're getting into the ecosystems
and then they're getting into lungs
and things like that in this location.
I've taken that sample on that day.
I can then map back where it's traveled
through time in the air,
and then where it came from potentially.
So there is moving forward.
It's a way of not finger pointing,
but like identifying the key sources
that can be the major contributors
to what this atmospheric plastic is.
Yeah, yeah.
I wanted to ask about this.
And I actually got a question from a watcher
of the series here,
that I think I just might as well kick to, from Laura Tate.
She was wondering, I think both of you
can answer this, it's big enough on a planetary scale.
Is it too late to save the planet?
If not, what are the top three things
we can do to stop the destruction of Earth
for our future generations?
We're closing out here on a couple of last minutes.
I hope we can end on a bright note in that way.
I hope we can!
We're not gonna give up hope, we're gonna try.
Yeah, I think-- I--
Go ahead.
[stammering]
[laughing]
For plastics, there are some basic things we can do.
We use an enormous amount of single-use plastic.
If you think about and evaluate the plastic
that you use on a daily basis
in a different way,
so you identify this as a very high value resource,
not something that you use for a single purpose,
and then dispose of.

and try to help these ecosystems along

change in ways that it'll be unrecognizable

and that new, different climate system in the future.
Hmm, wait, sorry.
Two minutes left.

building off a little bit of that.
